user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_get_username:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN char *
MHD_digest_auth_get_username (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params;
  char *username;
  size_t buf_size;
  enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type;

  params = MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ (connection);
  if (NULL == params)
    return NULL;

  uname_type = get_rq_uname_type (params);

  if ( (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD != uname_type) &&
       (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED != uname_type) )
    return NULL;

  buf_size = get_rq_unames_size (params, uname_type);

  mhd_assert (0 != buf_size);

  username = (char *) MHD_calloc_ (1, buf_size);
  if (NULL == username)
    return NULL;

  if (1)
  {
    struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo uname_strct;
    size_t used;

    memset (&uname_strct, 0, sizeof(uname_strct));

    used = get_rq_uname (params, uname_type, &uname_strct,
                         (uint8_t *) username, buf_size);
    if (uname_type != uname_strct.uname_type)
    { /* Broken encoding for extended notation */
      free (username);
      return NULL;
    }
    (void) used; /* Mute compiler warning for non-debug builds */
    mhd_assert (buf_size >= used);
  }

  return username;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided snippet. The code does not contain vendor-specific keywords or tokens that are documented compiler extensions, such as __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, __builtin_*, __extension__, typeof (as a GCC extension), __inline__ (implementation-specific forms), or #pragma with vendor-specific pragmas. All constructs shown are standard C: enums, size_t, casts, function calls, standard block scope and memset/free usage. The identifiers/macros starting with or containing underscores (for example _MHD_EXTERN or function names ending with an underscore) may be macros that in other translation units expand to implementation-specific attributes, but that expansion is not visible here. Per the instruction to report only explicitly used compiler extensions, these cannot be flagged based solely on this snippet, so no fragments are reported for investigation.
